required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Training in Exercise Activities and Motion for Growth
clinical_study.official_title: Training in Exercise Activities and Motion for Growth (A Study Conducted by the Pediatric Heart Network)

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: To determine if an exercise program of passive range of motion (ROM) is safe and feasible in infants with single ventricle (SV) physiology after their Norwood procedure.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a non-randomized pilot study to evaluate the safety and feasibility of an exercise program in hospitalized infants with single ventricle physiology. Following the Norwood procedure, the intervention will be administered for up to 21 days or until discharge, whichever comes first. Data will be collected daily during hospitalization and at a follow-up visit at 3 months of age. Sources of data will include medical record review. Twenty subjects will be enrolled at three Pediatric Heart Network study sites (Utah Primary Children's Hospital, Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and Texas Children's Hospital). Subjects will be recruited following Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval at each institution and parental/legal guardian consent.

primary_outcome.measure: Adverse Events (AEs) and Serious Adverse Events (SAEs) in a Passive ROM Exercise Program, Administered up to 21 Days After the Norwood Procedure, in Infants With Single Ventricle Physiology
primary_outcome.time_frame: during the intervention and for one hour afterwards, daily up to 21 days
primary_outcome.description: Number of adverse events (AE), of any type, occurring during and for one hour after the daily study intervention is concluded Number of AEs that are possibly or probably related to the intervention occurring during and for one hour after the daily study intervention is concluded Number of Serious Adverse Events (SAEs) possibly or probably related to the intervention occurring at any time during the 21 day intervention period

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of a Passive ROM Exercise Program, Administered up to 21 Days After the Norwood Procedure, in Infants With Single Ventricle Physiology
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of days with high completion, medium completion, and low completion of the intervention: High completion is defined as >75% of the intervention Medium completion is defined as 50-75% of the intervention Low completion is defined as <50% of the intervention Percentage of days with high/medium/low completion was then calculated across all participants and days

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs) in a Passive ROM Exercise Program, Administered up to 21 Days After the Norwood Procedure, in Infants With Single Ventricle Physiology
primary_outcome.time_frame: during the intervention and for one hour afterwards, daily up to 21 days
primary_outcome.description: • Number of participants with adverse events (AE), of any type, occurring during and for one hour after the daily study intervention is concluded

arm_group.description: A 10 - 15 minute passive range of motion (ROM) exercise program will be administered daily during hospitalization for up to 21 days or until discharge (whichever comes first).

intervention.description: After their Norwood surgery, stable subjects will undergo passive ROM exercise therapy for up to 21 consecutive days or until hospital discharge, whichever comes first. Subjects will have completed the study after their anthropometric measurements are collected at 3 months of age

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Hospitalized infants with SV physiology
- >37 weeks gestation
- <30 days of age
- Hemodynamically stable (as defined by the attending physician) after surgical or interventional palliation with closed sternum
- Parent or guardian willing to comply with protocol and provide written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Intrauterine growth restriction
- Chromosomal or recognizable phenotypic syndrome of non-cardiac congenital abnormalities associated with growth failure (for example Trisomy, Noonan or Turner syndromes)
- Unstable hemodynamics as defined by the attending physician
- Non-cardiac diagnosis associated with growth failure
- Severe neurologic injury resulting from stroke or intracranial hemorrhage confirmed by head CT/ MRI or cranial ultrasound
- Anticipated discharge within 14 days of screening

facility.name: Baylor College of Medicine - Texas Children's Hospital

group.title: Passive Range of Motion (ROM) Exercise
group.description: A 10 - 15 minute passive range of motion (ROM) exercise program was administered daily during hospitalization for up to 21 days or until discharge (whichever came first). Passive range of motion (ROM) exercise: After their Norwood surgery, stable subjects underwent passive ROM exercise therapy for up to 21 consecutive days or until hospital discharge, whichever came first. Subjects completed the study after their anthropometric measurements were collected at 3 months of age

event.sub_title: increased work of breathing with feeds

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
